Ok, I admit it, these are chick flicks. But they are really, really good chick flicks. Coal Miner's Daughter follows the life of Loretta Lynn and Fried Green Tomatoes is just a wonderful, wonderful make you laugh until you pee your pants and then cry until there are used tissues all over the floor kind of movie. The acting in both movies is so very good. I especially love Fried Green Tomatoes. What those women do to that man is so unthinkably horrible you'll feel guilty for laughing as hard as you will. Get a bowl of popcorn and your favorite fuzzy blanket and settle in for a good night of viewing. Oh and don't forget the tissues.

Fried Green Tomatoes

Very well acted comedy/drama about the friendship (and unspoken love) between two young women in the 1920's south.  Jessica Tandy, Mary Louise Parker and Mary Stuart Masterson are all terrific, and the story is sweet and entertaining.

But there's something just a bit dishonest (or skittish) in the film's resolute refusal to deal with it's own homoerotic inferences, and a few too many times I could feel the film's conscious intent to push my emotional buttons in the dramatic sections.

That said, still well worth seeing for the strong acting, and warm sense of time and place.

Coal Miner's Daughter:

An interesting and well acted mainstream bio-pic.

Sissy Spacek is amazing as Loretta Lynn - all the more so for doing her own singing (as did Beverly D'Angelo as Patsy Cline). Tommy Lee Jones shows more sweet charm than he's almost ever been allowed to since.

But in the end, it is indeed a Hollywood bio-pic, without any great overriding themes or ideas, except to tell the story of a fascinating woman's life one episode at a time.

A solid, engrossing film, but not quite a great one.
